indexPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

indexClinicalNotes: 78-year-old female admitted with acute decompensated CHF. BNP 2840, required IV furosemide and BiPAP. Responded to diuresis over 5 days. EF 30%. Weight decreased 8 lbs. Discharged on lisinopril, carvedilol, furosemide 40mg BID, spironolactone. Follow-up in 7 days with cardiology.
indexDischargePlan: Discharge to home with VNA services. Daily weights. Low-sodium diet education. Cardiology follow-up in 7 days. Return to ED if weight gain >3 lbs, worsening dyspnea, or chest pain.

readmitPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

readmitClinicalNotes: 78-year-old female readmitted 8 days after discharge for recurrent CHF exacerbation. Patient reports dietary noncompliance over holidays, gained 6 lbs. BNP 1920. Restarted IV diuresis. Did not follow up with cardiology as scheduled. Medication reconciliation shows patient ran out of furosemide 3 days prior to readmission.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission has the same principal diagnosis category as the index admission (I50.33 -> I50.33: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure). This strongly suggests the readmission is clinically related to the index stay and may represent incomplete treatment or disease recurrence.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Review index discharge to assess whether treatment was adequate. Evaluate if the readmission could have been prevented with more aggressive treatment, closer follow-up, or extended index stay.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission notes indicate gaps in post-discharge follow-up: missed appointments, medication noncompliance, or incomplete treatment courses. These gaps contributed to the readmission and suggest the discharge plan was inadequate or patient adherence support was insufficient.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Review discharge planning process. Consider enhanced transitional care: 48-hour post-discharge phone calls, medication delivery programs, and home health assessment. Refer to case management for high-risk patient identification.

agentSummary: 2 findings identified. Readmission was potentially preventable (preventability score: 55%). HRRP target condition: CHF. Clinical relatedness: Likely Related.

indexClinicalNotes: 72-year-old female admitted with community-acquired pneumonia and acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Required 4L O2 via nasal cannula. IV levofloxacin and ceftriaxone. Improved clinically. Discharged on oral levofloxacin to complete 7-day course. Follow-up chest X-ray in 6 weeks.
indexDischargePlan: Home with oral antibiotics. Complete 7-day course of levofloxacin. Follow-up with PCP in 1 week. Chest X-ray in 6 weeks. Return to ED for fever, worsening cough, or difficulty breathing.
readmitClinicalNotes: 72-year-old female readmitted 7 days post-discharge with worsening pneumonia progressing to sepsis. Culture grew same organism (Streptococcus pneumoniae) as index admission. Did not complete oral antibiotic course — stopped taking after 3 days due to GI upset. Required escalation to IV meropenem. Suggests incomplete treatment of original infection.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission has the same principal diagnosis category as the index admission (J18.9 -> J18.9: Pneumonia, unspecified organism). This strongly suggests the readmission is clinically related to the index stay and may represent incomplete treatment or disease recurrence.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Review index discharge to assess whether treatment was adequate. Evaluate if the readmission could have been prevented with more aggressive treatment, closer follow-up, or extended index stay.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission represents progression or recurrence of the index condition. Shared diagnosis codes: J18.9, J96.00. Clinical notes indicate the index condition was not fully resolved at discharge.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Review whether the index treatment course was adequate. Evaluate if the index length of stay was sufficient for clinical stabilization. Document root cause for quality reporting.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission notes indicate gaps in post-discharge follow-up: missed appointments, medication noncompliance, or incomplete treatment courses. These gaps contributed to the readmission and suggest the discharge plan was inadequate or patient adherence support was insufficient.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Review discharge planning process. Consider enhanced transitional care: 48-hour post-discharge phone calls, medication delivery programs, and home health assessment. Refer to case management for high-risk patient identification.

readmissionFindings.description: Both admissions have identical DRG assignments (193: Simple Pneumonia & Pleurisy w MCC) within 7 days. This pattern is consistent with DRG unbundling — splitting a single episode into two admissions to bill two DRG payments. Combined billing: $22,304.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Strongly consider bundling these admissions as a single episode of care. If bundled, reimburse only one DRG payment. Refer to Special Investigations Unit (SIU) if pattern is repeated across multiple patients at this facility.

indexDischargePlan: Discharge home. Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 12 months. Cardiac rehab starting week 2. Cardiology follow-up in 2 weeks. Echocardiogram in 6 weeks.

readmitPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

EF decreased from 40% to 32%. Post-MI heart failure is a known complication. Responded to IV diuresis. This readmission is directly related to the index MI hospitalization.

indexPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute exacerbation

indexClinicalNotes: 71-year-old female admitted with severe COPD exacerbation. Required BiPAP for 48 hours. IV methylprednisolone and nebulizers q4h. Sputum culture negative. Oxygen weaned to 2L NC. Discharged on prednisone taper and home nebulizer.
indexDischargePlan: Home with home oxygen 2L NC. Prednisone taper over 10 days. Albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer q6h. Pulmonology follow-up in 1 week. Smoking cessation counseling provided.

readmitPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute exacerbation

Patient had completed only 5 of 10 day prednisone taper. Continued smoking. No pulmonology follow-up occurred. Identical DRG as index stay — raises concern for premature discharge or inadequate discharge planning.

indexClinicalNotes: 74-year-old female admitted for elective right total hip arthroplasty. Surgery uncomplicated. Post-op day 1: ambulated with PT. Day 2: stairs training. Discharged on day 5 with home PT referral. DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin x 28 days.

This is a direct complication of the index surgical procedure. Postoperative complication — potentially preventable with different surgical technique or perioperative protocol.

readmissionFindings.description: Readmission for a surgical complication within 30 days of an elective surgical procedure. This is a patient safety indicator (PSI) event that should be reported. Consider whether the complication was preventable.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Report as Patient Safety Indicator event. Conduct surgical M&M (morbidity and mortality) review. Evaluate perioperative protocols (antibiotic prophylaxis, surgical technique, sterile technique). Flag for CMS quality reporting.

indexDRGDescription: Septicemia or Severe Sepsis w/o MV >96 Hours w MCC

indexDischargePlan: Home. Complete oral ciprofloxacin x 14 days total. PCP follow-up in 5 days. Repeat urinalysis in 2 weeks.
readmitClinicalNotes: 80-year-old male readmitted 24 days after discharge for cellulitis of right lower extremity. Unrelated to prior urosepsis admission. New condition — no prior skin complaints. Diabetic with peripheral neuropathy. Required IV vancomycin. This appears to be a new, clinically unrelated condition.
agentSummary: Readmission for Cellulitis of right lower limb appears clinically unrelated to the index admission for Sepsis, unspecified organism. Different diagnosis, appropriate timing. Separate payment appropriate.

indexPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

indexClinicalNotes: 69-year-old female admitted with mild CHF exacerbation. BNP 890. Responded quickly to one dose IV furosemide. Weight loss 3 lbs. Very short stay — 2 days. Discharged without medication changes. Minimal diuresis. Questionable whether full inpatient stay was warranted vs observation.
indexDischargePlan: Home. Continue current medications unchanged. Cardiology follow-up in 2 weeks. Daily weights.

readmitPrimaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

readmitClinicalNotes: 69-year-old female readmitted just 3 days after discharge with worsening CHF. Now with AKI on CKD. BNP 2100. Required continuous IV furosemide drip. Identical principal diagnosis to index stay. Very rapid readmission strongly suggests premature discharge from index admission — inadequate diuresis during 2-day stay. These two admissions may represent a single episode of care.

indexDischargePlan: Patient left AMA. Counseled on risks of premature departure including sepsis recurrence, organ failure, and death. Refused to sign AMA form. Prescriptions for oral antibiotics offered but patient left before receiving.

readmitClinicalNotes: 72-year-old female readmitted 2 days after AMA discharge with septic shock. Same skin source. Now with organ failure — AKI and hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors. These two stays represent a single episode of care interrupted by patient's AMA departure.

readmissionFindings.description: Same-day transfer between facilities. The index admission shows transfer discharge status and the readmission occurs on the same date at a different facility. Per CMS transfer rules, the transferring hospital receives a per diem payment and the receiving hospital bills the full DRG. Both facilities should not be billing full DRG rates.
readmissionFindings.recommendation: Apply CMS transfer DRG pricing rules. The transferring facility should receive a per diem rate (not the full DRG). Verify transfer agreement documentation. Flag for payment adjustment.
